title: French state can still be a party pooper in Fiat-Peugeot merger talks
text:
Earlier this year a proposed merger between Fiat Chrysler and Renault failed because of the French government’s clumsiness and its last-minute fears that the deal would further complicate the French carmaker’s delicate “alliance” with Nissan.

Now Fiat FCA, +9.58% has predictably turned to another French carmaker, Peugeot UG, +4.21% , and the two companies have confirmed The Wall Street Journal’s scoop that they have engaged in talks.

The merger, which would be based on an all-share transaction, looks simpler to achieve than the Renault deal because Peugeot is not saddled with a contentious imbrication with another carmaker. But the French state retains its capacity to botch the merger.

Fiat and Peugeot shares jumped on the news, up 7.5% and 6.2% respectively in mid-day trading on Wednesday, while Renault’s RNO, -4.60% sank 4%.

The merger would not only see Fiat thumbing its nose at the French government, but Peugeot chief executive Carlos Tavares thumbing his own at Renault. Portugal-born Tavares resigned from Renault, where he had worked 32 years and climbed to the number-two position under then-chairman Carlos Ghosn, after it became clear to him that he would not rise to the top.

The French government owns a 12.2% stake in Peugeot, the consequence of a 2014 multi-billion state-sponsored bailout of the company, then teetering near bankruptcy. China’s Dongfeng 489, -2.39% and the Peugeot founding family owns similar stakes, albeit with bigger voting rights.

Because the merger will be presented as one “of equals”, as it credibly can, and Tavares is expected to be the chief executive of the merged entity, the French government’s fears about a loss of control could be soothed. But you can still expect the usual noises from ministers about the necessary “vigilance” in the need to “protect jobs” in French factories.

A reasonable chief executive in a sensitive sector like the autos industry would normally check with their big shareholders when holding merger talks with a foreign competitor. So Tavares may have verified beforehand that there wouldn’t be political trouble. And Fiat-Peugeot looks like the ideal “pan-European” merger French President Emmanuel Macron is so keen on.

But if the Renault experience is any guide, Tavares also knows that the one predictable thing about the state as shareholder is its unpredictability.
description: The government’s 12% stake in Peugeot gives it potential meddling power
